newsitem.title: USA: Ex-prostitute fails in bid for U.S. Congress.
newsitem.headline: Ex-prostitute fails in bid for U.S. Congress.

text.p: Jessi Winchester, a former prostitute who once worked at the Moonlight Bunny Ranch, a legal brothel in Nevada, fell short of her dream of reaching the U.S. Congress on Tuesday.
Former state Sen. Thomas "Spike" Wilson crushed Winchester in the Democratic primary for Nevada's second congressional district on Tuesday.

Former state Assemblyman Jim Gibbons won the Republican primary and will face Wilson in the November election to choose a successor to U.S. Representative Barbara Vucanovich, a Republican who is retiring after 14 years in Congress.

In the race for Nevada's only other congressional seat, which encompasses the Las Vegas area, state Sen. Bob Coffin easily defeated three opponents in the Democratic primary to earn a shot at Republican incumbent John Ensign, who had no primary opposition.

Winchester retired after six years as prostitute, working at the Moonlight Bunny Ranch and the Mustang Ranch, both legal Nevada brothels. The 53-year-old grandmother drew national attention with her campaign for political office.

Although Winchester distanced herself from her former profession, her candidacy drew criticism from the Nevada Brothel Association, which represents brothels that operate legally in 10 of Nevada's 17 counties.
"Her behaviour flies in the face of a policy our industry tries to maintain of not rubbing our existence in people's faces," George Flint, a lobbyist for the association, said earlier this year.
With almost 90 percent of precincts reporting, Wilson had about 62 percent of the vote to Winchester's 21 percent, with Mike Martin, a security guard at a Reno casino, trailing on 17 percent.

In her low-budget, heavily-travelled campaign, Winchester derided Wilson, who served 14 years in the state legislature and, most recently, as chairman of the Nevada Ethics Commission, as "a professional politician" and "good old boy".
By contrast, she said she was "totally in touch with those who work more than 40 hours a week and have to figure out a budget."
Winchester said her former profession initially caused a stir on the campaign trail "but in the last few months I've had no questions. They saw me as a candidate, not as a hooker."
Speaking on Tuesday evening, Winchester said that political realities had engulfed her earlier optimism to the point where she would likely never seek major office again.
"I was just an average person trying to give some representation to the middle class. What I found was that the average person can't run," she said.
"Wilson and I didn't run against each other. He had the influence and power of the governor and two (U.S.) senators and their staffs. The average person just can't fight this thing," she said.
